awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Integrated Biorefinery for Pyrolysis Biofuels and Biotemplated Nanomaterials
awd_abstract_narration:
As the world?s population and energy demands increase, our global reliance on fossil fuel resources to provide this energy puts an incredible strain on the environment. The modern biorefinery could produce sustainable energy by converting lignocellulosic biomass to fuels through thermal and chemical routes. However, one of the primary issues with using pyrolysis (heating in the absence of oxygen) as a thermochemical conversion technique is the need for significant fuel upgrading to improve stability and increase the heating value of the oil. Though bio-oils can be upgraded post-production, current methods suffer from catalyst poisoning and high materials and operation costs. This research project aims to address these issues by incorporating inorganic compounds, such as metal nitrates and acetates into cellulosic feedstocks, to simultaneously engineer high-value nanomaterials via bio-templating and catalytically upgrade pyrolysis bio-oils, thus reducing the need for costly downstream upgrading. Using machine learning based techniques, such as materials informatics for potential catalyst selection and statistical design of experiments, to inform process variable decisions, the proposed work will add to a fundamental body of knowledge on in situ upgrading of thermochemically derived biofuels while offering a new paradigm in computationally informed, experimentally verified renewable fuel design.

The proposed research will focus on upgrading of biofuels during pyrolysis by simultaneously making bio-templated nanoparticles. Materials Informatics approaches will be used to select in situ pyrolysis catalysts and surrogate reactions will be used to predict (and then validate via integrated feedback loop) potential reaction pathways and formed nanomaterial structure.  By developing a new Pyrolysis Product Index that looks at where, for example, oxygen goes during pyrolysis, and how yields of marker compounds change upon catalyst incorporation, the principal investigators aim to synthesize a new way to discuss biofuel upgrading pathways, helping to standardize what is a rather diverse literature in terms of what is deemed to be a good pathway. The project also aims to elucidate the physical changes occurring during pyrolysis of metal-impregnated biomass using in operando Raman spectroscopy through an international collaboration with a group from Queens Mary University (United Kingdom). The objective is to improve our knowledge of which reaction pathways are most critical to devolatilization, and how to better design catalysts to improve both primary pyrolysis and to limit secondary reactions, such as re-condensation, and to promote cracking, thereby reducing tar formation. The proposed work also involves nanomaterials characterization to understand the process variables impacting size, morphology and crystallinity of bio-templated nanomaterials.  Advances in fundamental science stemming from the proposed work may lead to the design of an optimized integrated biorefinery to convert renewable sources to energy and materials. In addition to training graduate and undergraduate students in research, there ae plans to engage and mentor underrepresented students and develop and international graduate student exchange between Cornell, Boston and Queen Mary Universities. An active learning module for renewable energy applications will be developed, implemented and assessed in the three participating universities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: Proc Sys, Reac Eng & Mol Therm

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the potential to upgrade biofuels during pyrolysis by simultaneously forming biotemplated nanoparticles using a materials informatics guided selection of in situ “catalyst” materials and a statistical approach to process design decisions. To achieve this vision Boston University (BU) worked in collaboration with Cornell University. Research at BU focused on the use of materials informatics to identify transition metal (TM) catalysts that promote cellulose devolatilization, deoxygenation and/or tar reduction, and applications of machine learning to problems with sparse data. Applications of machine learning methods to materials science and other domains has exploded in recent years as the power of machine learning methods has become known to the wider scientific community. However, often machine learning methods are applied with little background knowledge of the methods and little thought into the selection of different methods for applications.

Initial research focused on the use of machine learning techniques to guide design of transition metal catalysts that promote the desired reactions/products and used existing literature data (CatalysisHub) to investigate correlations between activation energy and observed H2, CH4 and CO2 formation at Cornell. The pyrolysis process is known to involve hundreds of reactions that lead to the formation of gaseous and liquid products. Instead of trying to discern all of the possible reactions and considering the activation energy for each of them, we have used published data on reactions that are plausible during pyrolysis. CatalysisHub reports data on over 30 reactions involving C, O and H. Based on this initial list, 9 reactions were downselected for analysis in collaboration with Cornell. The activation energies associated with these 9 reactions for roughly a dozen transition metals, such as Ni, Mg, Cu, Zn, were analyzed and compared to data collected from experiments at Cornell.  A major challenge in this work is the lack of large, clean data. While there are databases and we have collected data, to effectively apply machine learning methods even larger datasets are needed. Additionally, missing, noisy, incorrect data can have a significant impact on machine learning results. 

Later research in this project focused on machine learning methods for better understanding materials and predicting material behavior. Various machine learning methods can be applied to materials systems and understanding which methods are appropriate and why has been the focus of research. Some methods such as neural networks are widely used but often applied to situations where they should not be. Neural networks require a large amount of data for training which is not often available for materials systems. Instead our research considers the kernel ridge regression (KRR) method as it requires less data while allowing for non-linear fitting of data. KRR was used to learn chemistry models based on experimental data and then combined with Bayesian Optimization to understand how changing material or operating parameters affect a material systems operation. This research was applied to reactor designs for carbon capture, showing the broader impacts of this research. This research was published in the journal Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research.

Finally research on the appropriateness of machine learning methods for different applications was further researched in relation to lithium batteries. In this work several different approaches such as Bayesian Optimization, Neural Networks, Gradient Descent, and Kernel Ridge Regression have been explored. The methods have been applied to current-voltage data for a lithium ion battery. The datasets contains a large amount of data as the battery was cycled for hundreds of cycles. 

Depending on the machine learn method applied different issues can arise. For instance Gradient Descent is a fast method but can have issues fitting the data if there are multiple local minima or maxima. While Bayesian Optimization produces more reliable fits it takes significantly longer times to run. Research into issues such as this have been done to better understand when to apply different machine learning methods. This research is currently being prepared for publication.   

 

 



 

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2024
Modified by: Emily M Ryan
